item.title: Cross-Group Interaction
item.description:
Status: nearing the end of data collection!

We’re studying whether interactions between strangers differ as a function of race. By comparing pairs of White participants with White/Black pairs we can investigate the effects of interracial interactions on a number of measures of understanding and empathy. Our dependent variables include action coordination, empathic accuracy, and dehumanization, plus neural measures including mu suppression and neural synchrony.

item.title: Demographic Ignorance
item.description:
Status: under review!

This line of work tests whether changing Americans’ perceptions of their country’s diversity affects their attitudes toward minorities. As you can see above, we’ve been surprised to find that making people think minorities make up a larger portion of the population actually decreases their implicit (and explicit) prejudice. It also decreases their conservatism.

item.title: Interpersonal Dehumanization
item.description:
Status: planning follow-up. Look for my poster at SPSP 2020!

We’ve run two studies testing whether we can manipulate perceptions of humanity with simple trait descriptions. We’ve found that our manipulation succeeds in making our targets less human, and that this predicts less attribution of pain (above), greater punishment, and more painful medical decision-making. However, we’ve also been manipulating targets’ race, but that has no effect. We are attempting to disentangle whether individual and group sources of dehumanization override one another or combine.

item.title: Multiple Categorization
item.description:
Status: in prep.

We’ve been using Representational Similarity Analysis to test whether we can decde the group identity of multiply categorized targets. Participants viewed videos of minimal in-group and out-group members who were also racial in-group or out-group members. We’ve found that we can easily decode either racial or minimal group identity, suggesting that both categories are simultaneous represented. We have yet to find a representational structure combining both categories.
